In addition, member stations must pay postage both ways on t apes shipped
to and from the Network. For a station in your area this would amount
to approximately $ 120.00 per year if you availed yourself of all the
programs made available by the Network. (There is a strong possibility
that there will soon be Congressional action to lower rates for educational
recordings, which would make postage payments considerably lower.) Even
with the postage charges you see that the cost per hour of programming
(for U00 hours, or more) is very low.
In addition to the regular Network service described above (a sample
Network offering is included in the material being sent separately),
we make available in-school programs to those stations who do in-school
broadcasting* for this service a station pays an additional fee of one-
fourth of the re ular assessment, or 2.00 per reel, whichever is less.
However, since many in-school stations are not on the air during the
summer months, such stations are allowed to substitute the in-school
programs for regular programs they would receive during the summer, and
thus pay no additional fee for the in-school service. If a station owned
and operated by a school or school systeji prefers to subscribe to only the
in-school programs, they may do this undp* a modified agreement. In this
case, the station gets all in-school programs, plus one hour a week from
the regular* Network offerings, for half the fee they would normally pay
for the full service. Of course, the conditions regarding postage payments
remain the same.
If, alter you’ve had an opportunity to look over the materials I’m sending,
you have any questions about the NAEB, please let me know, and we’re
looking forward to the opportunity of serving you.
